facts.text: Vrajlal Manilal Company, a firm consisting originally of four partners, has been doing business of manufacturing bidis at Sagar and Delhi since 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Vrajlal Manilal Company, a firm companysisting originally of four partners  1  Manilal Anandji,  2  Jivrajbhai Ujamshi Sheth,  3  Punjabhai S. Patel, and  4  Chintamanrao, has been doing business of manufacturing bidis at Sagar and Delhi since 1944.

facts.text: In 1954 Manilal Anandji retired from the firm.

anchor.surface_text: From time to time fresh partnership deeds were executed readjusting the shares of the partners admitting new partners and adjusting the shares of the partners. In 1954 Manilal Anandji retired from the firm and on January 27,1955, Punjabhai Patel died.

facts.text: On January 27, 1955, Punjabhai Patel died.

anchor.surface_text: In 1954 Manilal Anandji retired from the firm and on January 27,1955, Punjabhai Patel died. On February 16, 1956, a fresh deed of partnership was executed.

facts.text: On February 16, 1956, a fresh deed of partnership was executed with eight partners.

anchor.surface_text: On February 16, 1956, a fresh deed of partnership was executed. The firm then companysisted of eight partners-Jivraj and his two sons being entitled in the aggregate to annas -/4/3 share in a rupee in the profits, Chintamanrao and his two sons to annas -/7/6 share in a rupee, and the two sons of Punjabhai S. Patel to the remaining annas -/4/3 share.

facts.text: Jivraj and his two sons entitled to 4/3 annas share in profits.

anchor.surface_text: The firm then companysisted of eight partners-Jivraj and his two sons being entitled in the aggregate to annas -/4/3 share in a rupee in the profits, Chintamanrao and his two sons to annas -/7/6 share in a rupee, and the two sons of Punjabhai S. Patel to the remaining annas -/4/3 share.

facts.text: Chintamanrao and his two sons entitled to 7/6 annas share in profits.

anchor.surface_text: Jivraj and his two sons being entitled in the aggregate to annas -/4/3 share in a rupee in the profits, Chintamanrao and his two sons to annas -/7/6 share in a rupee, and the two sons of Punjabhai S. Patel to the remaining annas -/4/3 share.

facts.text: Paragraph 13 of partnership deed specified valuation basis for retiring partner's account: Goodwill as net profits of last five years.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph-13 provided In case of retirement of any partner the valua-, tion of the Firm will be made on the following, basis for the purpose of settling the account of the retiring partner- Goodwill of the Firm-That is, right to use the trade marks, trade labels and the name of the Firm. In making the valuation of the above the net profits of the last five years will be taken as the value of the Goodwill of the Firm.

facts.text: Outstandings to be calculated at 85% of book value per para 13.

anchor.surface_text: Outstandings, Udhari  Recoveries  -That is, loans and debts outstanding against persons other than partner will be calculated at 85 of the book value of the Firm.

facts.text: Stock of raw materials valued at book value per para 13.

anchor.surface_text: Stock of Raw Materials-That is, tobacco, bidis, bidi leaves, labels and other moveable property will be valued at the book value of these in the books of the Firm and all, such stock and moveables, thus valued shall be given to the remaining partners.

facts.text: Immoveable property valued at purchase price or book value per para 13.

anchor.surface_text: Immoveable Property-Such as buildings, godowns, gardens, lands etc. will be valued at the parchase price or their book value in the books of the Firm as the case may be, and all these shall be given to the remaining partners.

facts.text: In April 1958 Jivraj and his two sons desired to retire from the partnership.

anchor.surface_text: In April 1958 Jivraj and his two sons -appellants in this appeal desired to retire from the partnership, and a deed of reference was executed on April 16, 1958, appointing Ambalal Ashabhai, Becharbhai Somabhai and Chaturbhuj Jasani as arbitrators to decide the dispute.

facts.text: Deed of reference executed on April 16, 1958, appointing three arbitrators.

anchor.surface_text: In April 1958 Jivraj and his two sons -appellants in this appeal desired to retire from the partnership, and a deed of reference was executed on April 16, 1958, appointing Ambalal Ashabhai, Becharbhai Somabhai and Chaturbhuj Jasani as arbitrators to decide the dispute.

facts.text: Deed of reference modified to sole arbitrator Shri Jasani.

anchor.surface_text: The deed of reference was subsequently modified, and the parties agreed that the reference be carried out by the sole arbitrator Shri Jasani.

facts.text: Jasani made his award on January 9, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this modified agreement, Jasani entered upon the reference, and made his award on January 9, 1959.

facts.text: Arbitrator fixed value of goodwill at Rs. 32 lakhs including depreciation and appreciation of property, dead-stock and dues.

anchor.surface_text: By his award he fixed the value of the goodwill of the entire firm at Rs. 32 lakhs including in that amount the depreciation and appreciation of the property, dead-stock and dues to be recovered.

facts.text: Award specified amounts: Jivraj Rs. 3,46,223.58 nP., Amritlal Rs. 4,04,519.99 nP., Bhagwandas Rs. 3,86,019.14 nP.

anchor.surface_text: He also fixed the profits for the broken period of Samvat year 2014 from the companymencement of the year till April 19, 1958 at Rs. 2,80,000 and after adjusting the personal accounts of the three retiring partners awarded to Jivraj Rs. 3,46,223.58 nP.

facts.text: Award filed in Court of Additional District Judge, Sagar under s.14(2) Arbitration Act 1940.

anchor.surface_text: This award was filed in the Court of the Additional District Judge, Sagar, under s. 14 2  of the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940.

facts.text: Chintamanrao and sons applied to set aside the award.

anchor.surface_text: Chintamanrao and his sons then applied for an order setting aside the award on diverse grounds.

facts.text: Trial Court set aside the award upholding objections including arbitrator exceeding jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court upheld these and certain other objections, and set aside the award. The High Court companyfirmed the decision of the Trial Court, insofar as it related to the two objections hereinbefore set out.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court confirmed setting aside on April 30, 1962, in Misc. Appeal No. 75 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 717 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1962, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Misc. Appeal No. 75 of 1961.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on November 19, 1963, dismissing appeal.

anchor.surface_text: November 19, 1963. The Judgment of A.K. Sarkar and J.C. Shah, JJ. was delivered by Shah, J. M. Hidayatullah, J. delivered a separate Opinion.

facts.text: Court found arbitrator exceeded jurisdiction by including depreciation and appreciation in goodwill valuation.

anchor.surface_text: One thing, however, stands out prominently in the award, that in assessing the value of the goodwill, he has included the depreciation and appreciation of the property, dead-stock and the outstandings.

facts.text: Net profits of last five years Rs. 21,70,650 as admitted by Chintamanrao.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the retiring partners urged that on the admission made by Chintamanrao, the value of the goodwill alone was Rs. 21,70,650/10/and if the value of the immoveables, stock-in- trade etc.

facts.text: Outstandings aggregated to Rs. 9,16,366 at book value.

anchor.surface_text: On October 10, 1958, Chintamanrao produced a statement of the net profits of the five years preceding the date of dissolution-which he called the price of the goodwill-for Samvat years 2009 to 2013. The aggregate of the net profits was Rs. 21,70,650/10/which he called price of the goodwill.

facts.text: Arbitrator ordered production of accounts on various dates including Sept 16, 1958, Oct 10, Dec 1958.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated September 16, 1958, the arbitrator gave direction, amongst others, to Chintamanrao to file a statement of houses etc. of immoveable property, valuation of the same as shown in the books of account, i.e. figures regarding it, and also the approximate value statement as it existed at the date of demand according to the estimate of Chintamanrao.
This award was filed in the Court of the Additional District Judge, Sagar, under s. 14 2  of the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940.

An award made by an arbitrator is conclusive as a judgment between the parties and the Court is entitled to set aside an award if the arbitrator has misconducted himself in the proceedings or when the award has been made after the issue of an order by the Court superseding the arbitration or after arbitration proceedings have become invalid under s.35 of the Arbitration Act or where an award has been improperly procured or is otherwise invalid s.30 of the Arbitration Act.

arguments.claim: No power to remit or supersede as no prior request

anchor.surface_text: No such request was, however, made by them in the Trial Court or in the High Court, and we will not be justified in the circumstances of the case in acceding to that request.

holdings.text: The clauses of the partnership agreement were incorporated in the agreement of reference, binding the arbitrator to its terms.

anchor.surface_text: He had, in determining the amounts due to the retiring partners, to take final accounts with regard to the matters set out in cl. 4, as far as possible, according to and taking into consideration the terms and conditions of the Partnership agreement. By this direction the clauses of the partnership agreement were incorporated in the agreement of reference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deed of reference directs final accounts according to partnership agreement terms, compulsorily incorporating its clauses without option.

holdings.text: Arbitrator bound to strictly follow valuation methods in paragraph 13 of partnership deed: goodwill as net profits of last five years, outstandings at 85% book value, stock at book value, immoveables at book/purchase price; no discretion for depreciation or appreciation adjustments.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph-13 of the partnership agreement, in making valuation of the firm for the purpose of settling accounts, the value of the goodwill, the outstandings, stock of raw material and moveable and immoveable property had to be taken as directed therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Para 13 prescribes mandatory basis for valuation; language of compulsion in reference leaves no option to deviate.

holdings.text: Arbitrator exceeded jurisdiction by including depreciation and appreciation of property, dead-stock, and outstandings in goodwill valuation of Rs. 32 lakhs, contrary to para 13; constitutes error on face of award, rendering it liable to be set aside under s.30 Arbitration Act.

anchor.surface_text: One thing, however, stands out prominently in the award, that in assessing the value of the goodwill, he has included the depreciation and appreciation of the property, dead-stock and the outstandings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express statement in award shows deviation from incorporated para 13 limits; court determines jurisdictional bounds, not mere interpretation error.

holdings.text: Principle in Cruikshank v. Sutherland inapplicable, as partnership agreement explicitly prescribes book values, unlike silent articles there.

anchor.surface_text: The principle of Cruikshank and others v. Sutherland and others 1  on which reliance was placed by counsel for the retiring partners, has, in our judgment no application to this case,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit valuation rules in para 13 override general recasting principle where no specific method provided.

holdings.text: No need to decide legal misconduct ground, as exceeding jurisdiction sufficient to set aside award.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the case, we do not think it necessary to consider whether the plea raised by the remaining partners that the award is vitiated on the ground that the arbitrator accepted from the retiring partners documents...

holdings.reasoning_summary: First ground succeeds independently; unnecessary to address second.

holdings.text: Award not remitted to arbitrator under s.16 Arbitration Act, as no prior request made in trial court or High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the retiring partners submitted that on the view taken by us, the award should be remitted to the arbitrator under s. 16 of the Arbitration Act, 1940. No such request was, however, made by them in the Trial Court or in the High Court,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural requirement not met; court declines new request.

holdings.text: No order for supersession of arbitration agreement under s.19, as not requested.

anchor.surface_text: The retiring partners have also not asked for an order for supersession of the arbitration agreement in exercise of the powers of the Court under s. 19.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No application made; court refrains from considering.

holdings.text: Appeal dismissed; award properly set aside by courts below.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs in one set.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upheld lower courts on jurisdictional excess.

precedents.cited_proposition: book value not binding where partnership agreement specifies otherwise

anchor.surface_text: 1923 92 L.J. Ch. 136. The expression book value in the companytext in which it occurs in the partnership agreement means, the value entered in the books of account. Adoption of the book value is therefore obligatory and there is numberscope. of any adjustment in the value in the light of any depreciation or appreciation of the property, outstandings, stock-in-trade or dead-stock, apart from what may actually be included in the book value, in the books.

precedents.cited_proposition: partnership accounts prepared for one purpose not conclusive for retirement valuation

anchor.surface_text: Chempsey Bhara and Company v. Jivraj Balloo Spinning and Weaving Company Ltd. at p. 331 An error in law on the face of the award means, in their Lordships view, that you can find in the award or a document actually incorporated thereto, as for instance a numbere appended by the arbitrator stating the reasons for his judgment, some legal proposition which is the basis of the award and which you can then say is erroneous.

precedents.cited_holding: An error in law on the face of the award means... some legal proposition which is the basis of the award and which you can then say is erroneous

But the arbitrator has in the present case expressly stated in his award that in arriving at his valuation, he has included the depreciation and appreciation of the property, outstandings and dead-stock, and in so doing in our judgment the arbitrator has travelled outside his jurisdiction and the award is on that account liable to be set aside.

precedents.cited_proposition: court cannot probe mental process of arbitrator unless disclosed in award

Co. 1 where it was observed An error in law on the face of the award means, in their Lordships view, that you can find in the award or a document actually incorporated thereto, as for instance, a numbere appended by the arbitrator stating the reasons for his judgment, some legal proposition which is the basis of the award and which you can then say is erroneous.

precedents.case_name: Champsey Bhara & Co v Jivraj Balloo Spinning and Weaving Co
precedents.cited_proposition: arbitrator entitled to interpret contract; error not on face unless explicit erroneous legal proposition
